monogr.title: Londons Artillery : briefly containing the noble practise of that wothie [sic] societie: with the moderne and ancient martiall exercises, natures of armes, vertue of magistrates, antiquitie, glorie and chronography of this honourable cittie. By R.N. Oxon
monogr.author: Niccols, Richard

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
SInce in this vncharitable age, most men in suspending their iudgements, do more often shoote their arrowes of censure out of the bow of passion, then reason, I do here set foorth this Essay of my Poem, as a common Butt, with a resolution expecting more arrowes of enuie then loue; yet if any ingenuous, more out of their owne modestie, then perhaps my desert, shall here thinke any thing well done; let them know that I haue endeuoured to doe well, as one that loues doing well for it selfe, more then for thankes; If the enuious who thinke any thing absurd in another, which they account excellent in themselues, shall condemne this my endeauor, to honour my natiue London, and that exercise of Armes, maintained by the industrie a • d expence of her hopefull Infantrie as vaine: yet can they not, if they will say it is great • anitie, but euen out of enuie wih all say it is great loue, my loue to them their worth, and practise, hauing beene the first c • use that gaue life to this labour. To those that except against the title of my worke which I call Londons Artillerie, because it is an impropriety of speech, not communicable to those of this praise worthie Societie, I answer, that I • m constrained to impose this terme vppon the, both because by the ignorant vulgar, they are generally so called, and the French word Infantrie with other more significant & proper • re scarse intelligible to any common Reader. The su • iect or matter o • my ••• m take thus: armes being none of my profession of that I haue onely la •• e downe these few positions First 〈◊〉 th ••••
• ri •••• nor shoul • vse armes for his art or tra • e: that euery s • ate or commonwealth should rather imploy and traine vp their owne natiue people in martiall discipline
for their defence, then strangers: That practise and time doe produce both stronger men and better soldiers, then nature &.c. Of London, if any desire to know the aptenesse of scituation, goodnesse of soyle, holesomnes of aire, Antiquitie, deriuation of name, honour of Armes, dignitie and vertue of Magistrates, martiall Exercises, natures of vsuall armes both auncient and moderne, in this little worke, as through a glasse they may behold all these reflected frō the light of auncient & authentike authors The order and maner into which I haue digested this little labor is thus, I haue grounded an Inductiō to the ensuing Cantoes, on certain reliques of Roman Antiquity, found in the feild, adioyning to this hopefull Companies Campus Martius, vulgarly called the Artillerie garden, amongst which the Image of Minerua being one, I haue made her, beeing President of arts and armes, the Author of my Poem, deuided into ten Cantoes, to which I haue adioyned certain notes of Illustration in Prose, not out of affected singularity, it being a thing not vsuall, but both to explain such places, which to the ignorant and perhaps to some, who think themselues no common Readers, may seeme difficult, and also to confirme such points of historie, by the testimonie of approoued Authors, which in my Poem may seeme doubtfull: For thy better instruction (gentle Reader) I intreate thee to obserue, that this marke "against any verse stands as a note of direction to the same verse in the Illustrations. Thus hoping a charitable censure, I craue no other reward for my paines, but that thou feeding on the fruite of my labor maist well disgest it.
